editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE FIRST FLOOR; A FARCE. IN TWO ACTS. AS IT IS NOW ACTING At the Theatre Royal in DRURY LANE.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR C. DILLY, IN THE POULTRY. M.DCC.LXXXVII. [Price 1 s.]

div.head: TO THOMAS KING, Eſq
div.p: THE FOLLOWING FARCE IS INSCRIBED, AS A SINCERE ACKNOWLEDGMENT OF THE MATERIAL ADVANTAGES DERIVED FROM HIS EXTENSIVE KNOWLEDGE OF DRAMATIC EFFECT,

closer.signed: BY HIS MOST OBEDIENT AND FAITHFUL HUMBLE SERVANT, JAMES COBB.

div.p: THE Publication of THE FIRST FLOOR affords the Author an Opportunity, of which he gladly avails himſelf, to expreſs his Acknowledgments to the Performers, for the able Manner in which they exerted their Talents in Support of the Piece.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.byline: Written by the AUTHOR of the FARCE. And Spoken by Mr. BANNISTER, Jun.

lg.l: WELL, here you are—expectant all, no doubt,
Gueſſing what this ſame Farce can be about.
"The Firſt Floor! La!"—exclaims a City Dame,
"Upon my word, a monſtrous pretty name!
"Deary, we'll go and ſee it—there are jokes,
"Depend upon it, on low vulgar folks,
"Who into naſty lodgings needs muſt pop;
"And can't afford, like us, to keep a ſhop."
"Tell me, Sir Harry,"—liſps a titled fair,
"What is this Farce—and pray who will be there?
"Shall one be vapour'd with their empty rows,
"Or bleſt in crowds of faces that one knows?"
"Can't ſay, 'pon onnor, Ma'am," replies Sir Harry:
"As for the Piece—ſuppoſe it can't miſcarry,
"If cramm'd with jeſts on us, as heretofore,
"To make the creatures in the galleries roar.
"Theſe Firſt Floor Authors are quite new to me—
"I thought they liv'd in Garrets—He! he! he!"
"Lud,"—cries her ladyſhip,—"I dare to ſay
"This Firſt Floor points at poor dear Lady K.
"She ſupt with we know who—we all know where—
"Some folks have taken lodgings near the ſquare.
"Thus to ſtab characters, one's feeling ſhocks—
"John—run to Foſbrook—I muſt have a box."
"Pſha!" ſnarls old Quidnunc—"I'll lay five to "four,
"There's nought but politicks in this Firſt Floor.
"Sly ſtrokes at Miniſters—I ſmell a rat—
"Botany Bay—the Treaty—and all that."
"Done," ſays Jack Spruce,—"I'll bett you what "you pleaſe,
"They will be witty on the ladies keys:
"Or, as the laſt new joke their purpoſe ſuits,
"Abuſe box-lobby heroes, and their boots."
Now, while conjecture marks each ſapient phiz,
I'll give you juſt a ſketch of what it is.
Our Firſt Floor's fitted up, in hopes of ſtriking
Thoſe who to mirth and whim bear hearty liking:
In whom by faſhion, nature, ne'er ſuppreſt,
With burſts of honeſt laughter greets each jeſt.
Our Floor thus lett—the graver critics ſcorning,
We hope our Lodgers will not give us warning.

div.p: Memorandum:—Such parts as are marked with inverted commas are omitted in the repreſentation.

div.head: SCENE I. An Inn in London.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: WELCOME to town, your honour!—a long while ſince I ſaw your honour—was ſaying but this very morning that it was many months ſince I ſaw my worthy maſter, Squire Monford.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Say ſo ſtill, Landlord—for I am come to town incog, and wiſh to conceal my arrival here.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Ah! a pair of fine eyes in the caſe! you have ſprung all the game about the country, and now you are coming to poach on ſome poor fellow's manor in London.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: No faith, there is no poaching in the caſe; I mean to take out a licence for ſporting on a certain manor, call'd Matrimony.

sp.speaker: "Land.
sp.p: Matrimony! Lord, Sir, 'tis well enough for your dog-trots—we muſt, to be ſure, have cattle for the high road buſineſs of life; but who the devil wou'd think of running a racehorſe in a poſt-chaiſe?—'tis time enough to put him in harneſs when he is no longer able to win a ſweepſtakes.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: Why look'e, Landlord, I don't think that twenty years of diſſipation will qualify me the better for a huſband: I look on marriage as a ſort of partnerſhip, in which I mean to engage whilſt I can bring youth, good ſpirits, and a good conſtitution, as my ſhare of the ſtock in trade: but when a pretty girl finds herſelf intrapp'd into a connection with a bankrupt trader, can he be angry with her for taking meaſures to diſſolve the partnerſhip?"

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Well, your honour—and this intended fair partner of yours—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: She is coming to town with her father, and will be in this houſe in the courſe of an hour or two.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: The old ſtory, I ſuppoſe—the father averſe to the match.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Yes, unfortunately for me—but my charmer has conſented to a private marriage; I am now going in ſearch of lodgings for us, and ſhall be with you again preſently.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p:
Ah! there he goes—as pretty a fellow, aye, and as good a cuſtomer, as an inn-keeper wou'd wiſh to live by—never knew him look at
the items of a bill in my life—always paid it the moment he ſaw the ſum total, and ſubmitted to be cheated like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Landlord! how are you, my boy? Come, let's have a glaſs [ſitting down at the table] you are a jolly fellow.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And i'faith you ſeem to be the ſame—I think it is now three days ſince you came to town on the Bury-fly, during which time you have ſcarcely been ſober three hours.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Pſha! pſha! 'tis only my not being us'd to ride on the roof of the coach that made me giddy—a ſudden exaltation may turn better heads than mine.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And pray have you no buſineſs in town?

sp.speaker: "Simon.
sp.p: None of my own.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: But you have ſome of your maſter's?"

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Yes, I have a letter from my maſter to his ſon, which I was order'd to deliver directly, but faith I forgot it; "and it don't much ſignify: I hate to be a meſſenger of ill news.

sp.speaker: "Land.
sp.p: You know the contents then?

sp.speaker: "Simon.
sp.p: Yes, yes; my old maſter is coming to town to viſit his ſon:" aye, here is the letter.—To Mr. John Whimſey, Junior, at Mrs. Pattypan's, Paſtry-cook, in Piccadilly.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Hey-day! why you are not going to open your maſter's letter?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p:
Certainly I will; my maſter wou'd make
no ceremony in opening a letter of mine— [reading the letter] Dear John, I ſend you this by my man Simon, who will deliver it to you immediately on his arrival in London—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: And you have been here three days already.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Come, Landlord, you don't drink—here's t'ye— [drinks.]

p.hi: I am coming to town to compleat the purchaſe of my neighbour Squander's eſtate, and ſhall take up my quarters at your lodgings for two or three days; I ſhall bring your ſiſter with me, as I hear there is a rakiſh young dog, of the name of Monford, has taken it in his head to fall in love with her, and I don't chuſe to truſt her out of my ſight.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Zounds! why did not you tell me at firſt who was your maſter.— [Aſide] If I had but known it before Monford left the houſe!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Why, between you and me, I am halfaſham'd to own my maſter—he is as ſuſpicious of every body about him, as if he had been bred a rogue himſelf—"a ſervant has not much credit in the place, I aſſure you."

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Hey-day! here's a poſt-chaiſe come to the door.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: With my maſter and his daughter in it, as I live.

sp.speaker: WHIMSEY
sp.p: Mind the portmanteau, ſirrah, d'ye hear, and take care none of the bundles are ſtolen.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Aye, there, his ſuſpicions are beginning already—if he has loſt but a button from his coat, he'll put the poſtillion to his oath, and have the very horſes taken before a magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: "Land.
sp.p: Well, I muſt run, and prepare to receive him.

sp.speaker: "Simon.
sp.p: Yes, ſo muſt I; and with the ſame kind of reception—a good lye, and a ſmiling countenance."

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: This way, Madam—this way, Sir—I hope your honour has had a good journey.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: No, I have not had a good journey; I have had lame horſes, and drunken drivers—duſt from the road—extortion from the inn-keepers, and bad halfpence from the turnpikes.—A blight upon honeſty and good manners blows from this city of London, to every point of the compaſs.—It is a mere ocean of knavery, with a continual ſpringtide, which infects all the ſtreams of freſh-water round the country, and makes them brackiſh up to their very ſource.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, your honour, travelling is very dear now.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Dear, with a vengeance!—I remember the time when a man cou'd be choak'd upon a duſty road for ſeven pence a mile; but now one muſt pay a ſhilling a mile for the pleaſure of being ſmother'd, becauſe it is one of the luxuries of life.— [To Charlotte.] You have not loſt your watch, have you?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh, no, Sir, all is ſafe about me— [aſide] except my heart.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: My pockets were all ſafe when I got out of the chaiſe; I ſuppoſe I have hardly loſt any thing ſince I came into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, what do you mean?—In my houſe!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Egad, I don't know, friend; but there are much finer houſes than yours in this town, where a man may go in with full pockets, and come out with empty ones.—But where is my raſcal?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: [coming forward] Here am I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Well, ſirrah, I ſuppoſe my ſon and you have been laying your heads together to cheat the old fellow, when he came to town—what did he ſay when he read my letter?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: He preſents his dutiful reſpects, and anxiouſly expects the pleaſure of ſeeing you—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p:
Go to be buried, I dare ſay he does—but I'm reſolv'd to live temperately, out of ſpite to him.—Landlord, ſee if the coach is come [Exit Landlord]. And you [to Simon] go and ſee all the luggage put ſafely into it— [Exit Simon]. Come, Charlotte, uncloud your countenance—
don't tell me of having loſt your heart—a young girl's heart is like a tame pigeon, let her throw it away ten times in a month, it will be ſure to come back again.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: The coach is ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Very well, be ſure then and take the number; and, d'ye hear, if there is any cordage from the trunks left, ſave it, Simon—though it be ever ſo little, it may ſerve to tie up ſomething or other.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir, if it is but a yard of rope—I think I ſhould know how to apply it properly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mr. Whimſey, your behaviour is beyond all bearing—It is a diſgrace to any ſober family to have ſuch a rake for a lodger.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Come, come, my dear Mrs. Pattypan—thou peerleſs princeſs of all paſtry-cooks—let us talk over the matter coolly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Talk, indeed! I'm tir'd of talking Mr. Whimſey.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: I'm glad of it—I never expected you would have been tir'd of that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: What ſignifies reaſoning with you? you are ſo thoughtleſs, ſo diſſipated—keep ſuch company, and ſuch hours—you'll ſhorten your days.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: But then, as the old ſaying is, I lengthen my nights, Mrs. Pattypan, and ſo it comes pretty nearly to the ſame end.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: How often muſt I beg of you to quit the premiſes? I've given you warning every day for this month paſt, and you won't take it.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: 'Tis a common complaint againſt young people, that they won't take warning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: I have put up a bill in the ſhop window already—A Firſt Floor to be let furniſhed—it will not long remain empty, I dare ſay—nay, a gentleman was here juſt now to view the apartments.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: You take equal care of your lodgings as of your heart, I perceive, Mrs. Pattypan—you let nothing of yours remain long unoccupied—I think your late huſband has been dead about two months, and you are now preparing for the reception of a ſecond.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Who do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: I mean your apprentice, Tim Tartlett; and a very good choice too, let me tell you, Mrs. Pattypan, he has ſerv'd his time to his maſter's buſineſs—and, I dare ſay, you will find him a very uſeful partner—But I ſee him coming, and I won't interrupt a love converſation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p:
I underſtand your ſneers, Sir. But
I hope, before you quit the houſe, you mean to diſcharge your debts—you are pretty much in my books.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: That is owing to my great reſpect for you—I hope I ſhall never be out of your books—Adieu, my dear old girl! If I can't get a bed elſewhere—perhaps I may pop in here—ſo you'll let your maid Nancy ſit up for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Impudent fellow!
Oh, your ſervant, Sir; ready dreſt, I ſee, for going abroad; you are always gadding, Tim Tartlett.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Lord, Miſtreſs! why, you are always ſcolding one for taking a little harmleſs recreation—you know I loves to ſee life—becauſe vy, 'tis ſo agreeable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and is there nothing due to me for my attention to you? What do you think made me take you from your father's poor hovel in the country, and place you in my own family?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'm ſure I can't tell, Miſtreſs; you muſt know beſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Hav'n't I put money in your pocket, and made a gentleman of you?—have not I taught you breeding?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p:
Have not I at length reſolv'd to
make you maſter of my ſhop, my fortune, and myſelf?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: But then you won't let me be my own maſter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Your own maſter, indeed!—then you wou'd be ruin'd preſently.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Vell, and if ſo be I vas, what then? Vy there's ſome of the great folks, that paſs in their ſtrip'd coaches and pheatons, and look as fine as a king on a twelfth-cake—our Nancy ſays they have been ruin'd for ſome years—and yet, i'cod, they ſeem as gameſome and airy as if nothing had happen'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Our Nancy, indeed!—there is another of your follies; always laughing and hallooing with that trapes in the ſhop, as if you were mad.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Vy, I can't help toying with her a little now and then, ſhe is ſuch a merry humourſome ſoul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: The trollop ſhall not ſtay within my doors—Oh, Tim, Tim! I wiſh you had pride enough to keep ſuch wretches at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Vy, ſo I have ſometimes—I can be as proud as Old Scratch to our journeymen and the ſhop-boy—but when I looks at a pretty girl, Lord, miſtreſs, all my pride melts away, like our icecream in the ſunſhine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Don't provoke me, Timothy—I declare—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: The card in your ſhop-window informed me, Madam, that you have a Firſt Floor to let ready furniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and as pretty a floor, tho' I ſay it—will you pleaſe to look at the rooms?

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I have ſeen them already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Oh! you are the gentleman who call'd juſt now, while I was out.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I only wiſh to know, whether I can take poſſeſſion of the lodgings this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: This hour, Sir, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I expect my ſiſter from the-country this evening; and as I cannot accommodate her at my chambers, am oblig'd, at this ſhort notice, to take lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I am now going to the place where ſhe will arrive, to leave a card of your ſhop, and ſhall be back time enough to receive her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Short and ſweet, indeed!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I wonder vether his ſiſter is a comely girl?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: What is that to you, Sir?—Do, be ſo good as to ſend your favourite Nancy to me immediately—we muſt get every thing in order for the lady.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: If ſhe has but black eyes!—I likes black eyes monſtrouſly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Never to aſk the price of the lodgings!—I declare I can't tell what to make of him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'cod you'll make a pretty penny of him before you have done with him, I warrant.

div.head: SCENE a Room in Mrs. Pattypan's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what a litter this room is in!—I ſhall be aſham'd for the young lady to ſee it.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Ma'am, here is one of the oddeſt old gentlemen below; all we can get out of him is, that theſe are his ſon's lodgings, and he will come up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: His ſon's lodgings!

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: There is a young lady with him, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Oh! the ſiſter of my new lodger, undoubtedly—ſhew them up immediately.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: They are ſhewing themſelves up, Ma'am—here they are.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ma'am, your moſt obedient—I find my ſon has taken lodgings here—I preſume you are Mrs. Pattypan.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: At your ſervice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Then we are all right—and ſo you are welcome to your brother's lodgings, Charlotte—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: That you are, Madam, I'll be ſworn—Your brother ſeem'd very anxious for your arrival, he will be home ſoon.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: There, Sirrah, put the portmanteau in the corner—one ſhou'd always have an eye to one's property. "[To Mrs. Patt.] Well, Mrs. Pattypan, what do you think of my ſon—how d'ye like him for a lodger?"

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: "Indeed, Sir, he ſeems to be a mighty civil, agreeable young gentleman—quite the reverſe of my late lodger—a diſſipated good-for-nothing—but" give me leave to ſhew you the apartments, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Mrs. Pattypan, let us have tea as ſoon as you can—I am rather fatigued with my journey. [Exeunt Mrs. Pattypan and Charlotte. [Whim. ſolus.] I'faith, I like Jack's lodgings mightily—here are all the pictures I gave him, and the library of books—he has taken great care of them, I ſee—all look as good as new; and not a volume diſplac'd—he is a careful reader, I dare ſay—I ſhall fancy myſelf quite at home among my old acquaintance. [Looking round] But who have we here?

sp.speaker: MONFORD
sp.p: [ſpeaking as he enters] Let me know the moment the lady comes.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p:
[Aſide] Some friend of my ſon's, I
ſuppoſe— [to him] Sir, your moſt obedient—very pretty apartments, Sir.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—I don't diſlike them.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I beg, Sir, you will be ſeated.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Sir, I, I— [Aſide] I ſee you don't wait for the ſame invitation.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: What d'ye think of thoſe pictures, Sir?—they are reckon'd pretty good.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: They ſeem to be very fine, indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Very glad you like 'em—I bought 'em—Indeed I partly furniſh'd this room.— [Rings the bell]

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Furniſh'd the room!— [Aſide] Some upholſterer, egad!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Let me have a pair of ſlippers, my lad, directly—I long to be out of my boots [Exit Frank] Nothing ſo pleaſant as to be perfectly at one's eaſe—that's my opinion—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: So I perceive, Sir!— [Re-enter Frank, Whimſey pulls off his boots.]

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I expect my ſon preſently—You'll ſtay to tea, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I believe I ſhall, Sir.— [Aſide] A moſt impudent old fellow this ſeems to be.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Believe I ſhall—he might as well have ſaid, thank ye.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide] A curious acquaintance my maſter ſeems to have pick'd up—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p:
Sir, I ſhould be exceedingly ſorry to be guilty of any rudeneſs to you—but I apprehend
you are not apprized who has taken theſe lodgings.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Oh yes, I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: In ſhort, I expect my ſiſter from the country every moment; and perhaps the preſence of a third perſon might not be quite agreeable to her.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Oh, as to that, I expect my daughter every moment too, and we may all drink tea together. [Tea brought in by Nancy] — [To Nancy] Do tell my daughter to make haſte. [Exit Nancy] — [Aſide] There can be no harm to invite him, as he is a friend of Jack's.—May I aſk your name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Monford, Sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Monford!—the very fellow who wants to run away with Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide to Monford] Miſs Whimſey is now in the houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: In the houſe!—Here, Frank, kick this damn'd portmanteau down ſtairs [Frank offers to take it, but Whimſey prevents him] You muſt really pardon me, Sir—any other time I ſhall be glad to ſee you. [Attempting to force Whimſey out.]

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir! What d'ye mean by that?

div.stage: Enter CHARLOTTE. Monford catches her in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p:
My Charlotte! am I indeed ſo bleſt as
to hold you in my arms again!— [to Whimſey] Give me leave, Sir, to introduce you to my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: [Aſide] Good heavens! what an adventure!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: A fine girl, Mr. Monford—Pray are you both by the ſame father?

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I am ſure, till this moment, I did not know I could boaſt of ſuch a hopeful offspring as you.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hear me, my dear father.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: [Aſide] His daughter!—a curſe on my unlucky ſtars!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Don't be diſappointed, young man—you have had a deviliſh lucky eſcape in miſſing my daughter, I aſſure you—for not a ſhilling wou'd I have given her, had ſhe thrown herſelf away on you.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: [Aſide] What the devil ſhall I ſay?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you are muttering curſes againſt the old fellow, becauſe he won't ſuffer you to hum him—come, uſe no ceremony—let me hear what I am.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: [Aſide] I have it—You are, Sir, indeed a friend.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: For depriving you of your wife—that is indeed the part of a modern friend.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: I thank you for your candour—you have diſcover'd to me my miſtake.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p:
You expected then that the old codger wou'd have whimper'd a little, join'd your
hands, and have given you half his fortune, for making a fool of him."

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: "I own it—but I ſee I was in an error." Miſs Charlotte, I thought you were a woman of fortune—your father has convinc'd me that you will no longer be ſuch, if you marry me; I ſhou'd therefore be guilty of the greateſt injuſtice in wiſhing to ſacrifice your happineſs to the gratification of my paſſion.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Sir—you—you are perfectly in the right—I feel the delicacy of your conduct—and—you may be ſure I approve it.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Give me your hand, Monford—Egad, I begin to think you are a deviliſh ſenſible fellow.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Between you and I, Mr. Whimſey, it won't do for younger brothers, like me, to fall in love.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Certainly not. It may well be call'd falling in love. 'Tis in truth a falſe ſtep, and many a man, who has once met with the accident, has found the ill effects of it ever afterwards.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Right, Sir, ſuppoſe now you were to recommend me to a wife—a rich widow, for inſtance.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Eh! why what ſay you to the lady of this manſion, Mrs. Pattypan?—My ſon Jack tells me, in his letters, ſhe is worth a round ſum.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: A good thought, Sir; with your permiſſion, I'll ſtep to Miſs Whimſey, and tell her my reſolution of courting the old lady directly.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Don't trouble yourſelf—I'll ſtep to Miſs Whimſey myſelf; and return immediately, to have a little more talk with you on the ſubject. Od'ſo! but while I am looking after my daughter, I may loſe my portmanteau.
sp.stage: [Exit Whimſey, and drags off his portmanteau.]

sp.speaker: "Frank.
sp.p: So, Sir, you are in a fine hobble here; this old man is the father of your miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: Even ſo, Frank—luckily a thought occurred to me, which I flatter myſelf has put him off his guard—I have pretended to give up his daughter, and pay my addreſſes to the old paſtry-cook below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: "Frank.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, this ſcheme is too abſurd to paſs on any man, however credulous he may be."

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: "To be ſure—but" if I can make him believe this abſurdity but for a few hours, all may yet be well—I think I can eaſily find means to convey my dear girl out of the reach of her father's power this evening.—Go inſtantly, Frank, and order a chaiſe to be at the corner of the ſtreet exactly at twelve o'clock.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt obedient humble ſervant.—I did not underſtand that you expected your father in town.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Nor I neither, Madam.— [Aſide] So I muſt paſs for the old fellow's ſon, I find.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you like the lodgings, and don't think them dear at three guineas a week.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Aye; I knew we ſhould agree, Sir, Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Egad, he has put the queſtion to her.— [Aſide] Monford, I perceive you have begun the attack.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: And have conquer'd too—only don't interrupt me in my victory.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Not I—you may ſay what you will before me.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: Aye; but the lady won't care to ſpeak before you. Pray now, Sir, leave us to ourſelves."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [to Whim.] Your ſervant, Sir, we had come to terms before you came in.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Oh, you had.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Yes; we were proceeding to ſettle every thing."

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Then I am ſure I wont interrupt you; and ſo good bye.— [Aſide] I'll take the liberty of liſtening to their converſation, however—nothing but the evidence of my own ears can remove my ſuſpicions.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Don't mind my father, Mrs. Pattypan, old folks have their peculiarities.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: True, Sir—I dare ſay it will be the ſame with you and I, when we grow old.— [Enter Whimſey, and retires to the back ſcene] But, however, to return to buſineſs—right reckoning makes long friends, as I us'd to tell my firſt huſband—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Aye, I dare ſay we ſhall be very happy together.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Happy together!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: I preſume, Sir, you generally dine out.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Conſtantly.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Zounds, that's odd enough! not to dine at home, during the honey-moon at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: And you keep good hours, I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Oh, yes, you'll always find me in bed by twelve o'clock.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide.] That's a material article.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I think you have no family, Mrs. Pattypan?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: No, Sir, I never had any yet—but as I think of altering my ſituation, it may happen that—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I underſtand you—but that will make no ſort of difference to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Indeed! I am very happy to hear it—for you know, Sir, ſome gentlemen have an objection to children.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Egad there can be no deceit in all this—it will be a match, I ſee that— [coming forward] [aloud] I wiſh you both joy with all my ſoul—don't be confus'd, Mrs. Pattypan—you know this is n't the firſt bargain of the ſort you have ſtruck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Oh dear, no, Sir; nor I hope it will not be the laſt.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] D—d good encouragement for a man to venture on her. I ſuppoſe ſhe expects to bury two or three huſbands yet.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: [Aſide to Whim.] Well, Sir, what do you ſay to all this?

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Why—why—why—you are a bold man, that's all— [Aloud.]" Come, as it is a bargain, take hands on it—take hands—nay, ſalute her—come, kiſs her, my boy.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide] My boy!—the old gentleman ſeems mighty fond of his ſon.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: [Aſide] Egad I wiſh this ceremony were well over, I ſhall never be able to carry on the farce. [Salutes her.]

sp.speaker: "Whim."
sp.p: [joining their hands] May you live long together, and may no domeſtic quarrels obtrude on your happineſs!—May you, Mrs. Pattypan, be ſurrounded by a numerous and lovely offspring!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide] A numerous offspring!

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Pray, my dear Sir, drop the ſubject—you ſee it diſtreſſes her; and you know one muſt conſult a woman's feelings on ſome occaſions.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Certainly! certainly!

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I am ſure I ſhou'd be ſorry to hurt Mrs. Pattypan's delicacy.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: So ſhou'd I—when a woman has but juſt enough left for her immediate uſe, it wou'd be cruel indeed to damage that—I'll change the ſubject, Monford, depend upon it. [He converſes with Mrs. Pattypan in dumb ſhew.]

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: [Aſide to Monf.] Sir, it is an impoſſibility for you to procure an interview with Miſs Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Impoſſible, Frank!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Abſolutely ſo—ſhe is ſo cloſely watched—but I've engag'd one in your intereſt, who will take any meſſage to her for you. No leſs a perſon than Mr. Timothy Tartlett.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: But how can he aſſiſt me?

sp.speaker: "Frank.
sp.p: By communicating to your miſtreſs any meſſage you wiſh; he will never be ſuſpected."

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Not a bad thought, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He is waiting to ſpeak to you below ſtairs—ſlip away from the old gentlemen directly.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Now, what the devil can they be whiſpering about?—I always ſuſpect a man to be a rogue when I ſee him whiſper. [Whimſey interrupts, and looks anxiouſly at them.] Eh! why you have not chang'd your mind as to matrimony, have you?

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, I promiſe you, Sir—I am now going on ſome buſineſs which, I flatter myſelf, will haſten the match, and a few hours will, I hope, cure all your ſuſpicions.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Egad, tho', I'll aſk the old woman ſome queſtions about him; there can be no harm in that.—Pray, Mrs. Pattypan, if I don't hurt your delicacy by the queſtion, how long may you have been acquainted with this young man whom you are going to marry?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide] Young man whom I am going to marry! how the deuce cou'd he hear of my intending to marry Tim Tartlett?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: You'll excuſe my curioſity—but pray is not he rather wild?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide] Yes, yes—he means Tim.— [to him] Why, Sir, I fear he is rather flighty—he has his little gallantries.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Look ye, Mrs. Pattypan—as to his little gallantries, as you call them, perhaps I know more of the matter than you do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you awaken my curioſity.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: But, really, when I conſider how diſagreeable a taſk it is to interfere between man and wife—for ſuch I conſider you to be—

sp.speaker: "Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Sir—in all the quarrels that I had with my poor dear ſoul that's dead and gone (and many they were) we never admitted any body to interfere, but fought them out by ourſelves.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: However, on this occaſion, my friendſhip for you overcomes every other conſideration."—In a word, your intended huſband has made love to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: What do I hear! I ſhall certainly faint.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [attempting to ſupport her] For Heaven's ſake don't faint yet, for I can't ſupport you, upon my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: An ungrateful fellow!—who owes all he has in the world to me!

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Then, of courſe, all he has in the world ought to be at your diſpoſal: but he did n't own to me that he was even acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: I have been a mother to him.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Perhaps he thought you fitter to be his mother than his wife.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. Patt."
sp.p: Oh, Sir, it is not to be repeated what I have done for that young man.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: If it is not to be repeated, I'm ſure I don't wiſh to hear it, Mrs. Pattypan.—But, between you and me—I ſuſpect the girl is fond of him.

sp.speaker: "Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Fond of him!

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Indeed I don't wonder at it—he is a handſome dog."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: He is, to be ſure, a likely young fellow—not that I conſider his perſon—the mind is my choice—what are fine eyes—flowing locks—brilliant complexions?—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [interrupting her] Mighty pretty things to look at, Mrs. Pattypan— [Aſide] Tho' you never found them in your glaſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: But what are they, compared to the beauties of the mind?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know—Compariſons are odious, and therefore I ſhan't attempt them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Beauty is but ſkin deep—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Then i'faith your ſkin conceals it more effectually than any ſkin I ever ſaw in my life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, how did you firſt diſcover this affair?—tell me all the particulars—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I would, if I had thought of it a little ſooner—but for aught I know, at this moment your ſcape-grace may be explaining to my daughter ſome particulars of which I ſhou'd wiſh her at preſent to remain ignorant—ſo it behoves me to look about me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: —Why, here they come!—yes, to be ſure!—Madam ogles, and ſimpers; how ugly ſhe looks when ſhe ſmiles!—
sp.stage: [Retreats to the back of the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And what time is the chaiſe to be ready?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: At twelve o'clock, Miſs—that was the time Squire Monford fix'd. Ah! how he'll be in the fidgets!—I know what it is to be a true lovier myſelf, as our Nancy can vitneſs.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Timothy, I own to you my courage fails me, now I come to the point.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I think your Ladyſhip ſeems to have a pretty good ſhare of courage, to come to the point ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: As to the matter of that, Miſs, as I told you before, I am as much in love as you are—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide.] A mutual declaration of love!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Never mind—by this time to-morrow you'll be out of your father's reach.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Gracious me! he is going to elope with her!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How the old gentleman vill ſtorm!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You know, as people grow in years, their ſentiments of love affairs naturally change.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: E'cod tho'—that is not the caſe with old Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Old Miſtreſs, indeed!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: By all accounts ſhe is juſt as loving now as ſhe was thirty years ago.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: [Aſide.] His ears ſhall pay for this.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: If the old girl was to hear me, now—what wou'd ſhe ſay to it! Ha! ha! ha!—Well, Miſs, I'll take my leave of you till twelve o'clock. I'm juſt a going to make merry with a few friends for an hour or two—I'll take care that you ſhall have an excellent chaiſe, and as good a pair of horſes as ever paſs'd Hyde-Park Corner.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Many thanks to you, kind Mr. Timothy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Courage, Miſs—true love endures to the end, as the ſong ſays. And ſo a fig for your father and old Mother Pattypan.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patty.
sp.p: [Coming forward.] Old Mother Pattypan! Old!—I ſhall run mad! What a plot!—'Tis lucky, however, I have diſcover'd it—I'll take care there ſhall be no elopement.—Old, indeed!—and too loving!—I don't know what the deuce the fellows wou'd have; when we are young, we are not half loving enough, forſooth!—and when a few years have taught us how to remedy the defect, they treat our improvement with contempt!

div.head: SCENE, a room in Mrs. PATTYPAN's houſe, with two windows in the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: AH! my dear little Nancy—how lucky I am, to meet with you alone.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I wiſh then, Sir, you would leave me alone as you found me: upon my word, Mr. Whimſey, I'll tell my miſtreſs how rude you behave.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Pray don't, my dear—ſhe will want to try my rudeneſs herſelf.—By the bye, where is the old woman?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: At a neighbour's over the way—you know ſhe is as jealous as Old Scratch of poor Mr. Timothy, and ſo ſhe means to watch his coming home.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Oh! ho! then ſhe is out [aſide] ſo much the better.— [to her] Nancy I want to give you a little good advice—ſtep into my room with me, and—

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Into your room! you have no room in this houſe, Mr. Whimſey; we have let the lodgings.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Let the lodgings! with all my furniture in them!—

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Pay what you owe, and you may have your furniture.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Death, and—but I can't ſtay to be in a paſſion—and ſo the lodgings are let?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Aye—there is an old gentleman, and one of the ſweeteſt young ladies—

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: A young lady!—Egad I muſt ſee her.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: And give her a little good advice too, eh?

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: To be ſure—nobody better qualify'd than myſelf to give good advice—I have receiv'd a great deal more than I make uſe of; and, as I ſcorn to be a miſer, am ready to give it away to any one who will take it.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Bleſs me, here comes Mr. Furniſh, the upholſterer, who has been ſo often after you with his bill, and our neighbour, Mr. Snap, the bailiff, with him, I vow.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Furniſh! that is the man to whom you have denied me ſo often—What ſhall I do—he never ſaw me, I believe?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Then I fear nothing. However, a little diſguiſe of my dreſs may not be amiſs—here is an old lac'd hat, and a morning-gown, which I gueſs, from its antique appearance, belongs to your old lodger.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Yes; his ſervant has juſt been unpacking his portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Then on they go—in caſes of neceſſity one cannot ſtand upon punctilio.
sp.stage: [Putting on the hat and morning gown.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Mr. Furniſh; I ſuppoſe you want Mr. Whimſey?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, I own a part of my buſineſs is with him.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I'll go and ſee if he's at home.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: You may ſave yourſelf that trouble, my dear: I am pretty ſure he is within.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: I think, Sir, Mr. Whimſey is indebted to you for the furniture of a houſe, taken by a very fine girl, who referr'd you to him for payment—I have read many of your letters to him.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—a number of letters paſs'd between us.—I ſuppoſe I have received a quire of paper from him at different times; and egad that is all I ever receiv'd from him.—You are his friend, I preſume, Sir?

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: I am partial to him, I own; tho' I confeſs he has been duped by women.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: That I can pardon, Sir. Gallantry has always been a part of my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Rather a ſmall part of your buſineſs at preſent, I ſhou'd think, Mr. Furniſh.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But you were ſpeaking of Mr. Whimſey, Sir;—I fear the poor gentleman is much diſtreſs'd.—Ah, Sir, there is no putting an old head on young ſhoulders.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: And, really, if that cou'd be done, I don't think it wou'd be any great addition to a man's appearance.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: I dare ſay you wou'd take pleaſure in affording him relief.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: That I wou'd, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Mine is not a large bill [giving him the bill] and I believe I cou'd afford to make a ſmall abatement in it—a trifling ſum will ſave an unhappy youth from diſgrace.—Conſider the exquiſite luxury of a feeling mind in relieving diſtreſs—conſider that generoſity is part of the buſineſs of man.—Conſider compaſſion— [Y. Whim. ſhakes his head.] You won't pay the bill—then come in Mr. Snap, and do your duty—follow me, and arreſt him directly.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Hey-day! what's become of the exquiſite luxury of a feeling mind in relieving diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: It may do very well for people of fortune; but a tradeſmen ſhou'd never indulge in luxury.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Conſider, generoſity is part of the buſineſs of man.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: And a d—d loſing trade it is—therefore it ſhan't be a part of my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! egad, Furniſh, you are very right not to engage in a buſineſs where you have no ſtock in trade to begin with.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: [Aſide to Y. Whim.] Lud, Mr. Whimſey, here is the old gentleman our lodger coming this way in a confounded huff about ſomething.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide to Nancy.] I'm very glad of it; I'll have a little ſport with the old boy—and engage him with Furniſh whilſt I get a peep at the young laſs.— [to Furn.] My dear Furniſh I've been jeſting with you hitherto I aſſure you.—So far from meaning to be young Whimſey's advocate, I wou'd adviſe you to arreſt him by all means.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: [Aſide.] What can he mean now?

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Let your friend, Mr. Snap, retire for a minute, and I'll explain myſelf.— [Exit Snap.] Between you and me, he is now here in diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Here! where?

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: You will ſee the old fellow preſently—Nancy tells me he is coming this way—

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I wiſh I dar'd laugh out.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Old fellow! Why I thought he was not above two-and-twenty.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Very true; but in his preſent diſguiſe he appears thrice that age.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: His preſent diſguiſe!

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p:
To deceive his creditors is, as you
call it, a part of his buſineſs. He wears as many different ſorts of wigs in a month as a barber's block; and all Monmouth-ſtreet can ſcarcely ſupply him with a ſufficient change of wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Egad, he muſt be a comical dog!—I ſhall be ready to laugh in his face.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Here he comes, I vow.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Aye, here he is— [aſide.] Eh!—what the devil—my father, by all that's whimſical!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir?—You are not going?

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: No, no, Sir;—only if Mr. Whimſey ſhou'd diſcover that I have told you this—a diſagreeable altercation might enſue.
sp.stage: [Goes to the corner of the ſcene.

div.stage: Enter OLD WHIMSEY, with open letters in his hand.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: What an extravagant dog is this ſon of mine!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: [Aſide to Y. Whim.] His ſon!—ſo he pretends to have a ſon:—that's a deviliſh good thought, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Egad it is lucky I broke open his letters and diſcovered his tricks. But I'll make him pay for all this when he comes home.— [turns and ſees Nancy.] Ah! my little bloſſom of beauty, are you there?— [Aſide.] To ſpend two hundred pounds upon a painted doll in three months!— [to her] Why, you look mighty pretty to-night, child! but what the devil are you tittering about?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Dear, Sir, I don't know—I'm in a merry humour, that's all.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ah! you dear little—Egad I'm in a merry humour too.—No,—I lye, I'm not merry— [Aſide] That ſcoundrel Jack—I'll diſinherit him.— [to her] Well, my little dear, and how d'ye do? the ſlut fires me—but then again that dog Jack fires me—ſo that I'm in a manner between two fires.

sp.speaker: "Nancy.
sp.p: You ſeem in a fluſter, Sir.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Yes, my love, I am in a fluſter— [Aſide.] That ſpendthrift!—What eyes ſhe has!—He muſt have his wench, forſooth!—the dog has no excuſe for his fault!—There is no reſiſting that girl, i'faith.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Well ſaid, Philoſophy at threeſcore.

div.stage: "[Juſt as Old Whimſey is going to take Nancy's hand, Furniſh comes forward.]"

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: [Aſide] Aye! aye! his young blood begins to boil—Mr. Whimſey, I kiſs your hand.—

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: A lucky releaſe.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Sir, your humble ſervant—You really have the advantage of me in knowing me.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I really deem it an advantage, and hope to avail myſelf of it—My name, Sir, is Furniſh.— [Aſide.] Who the deuce would think he is but two-and-twenty years old!—I hope you have had your health lately, Sir?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Very well, I thank ye; I have not been better for th • ſe forty years paſt.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Forty years paſt!—And then his coat—a deviliſh ſmart coat, to come from Monmouth-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Why, you ſeem to be mighty well acquainted with me, Mr. Furniſh.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I know you, Sir, by name, to be ſure; and I believe I can form a nearer gueſs at your age than any one would do merely from your appearance.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Angrily.] Eh! well, Sir, and how old do you ſuppoſe I am, then?—Damme, d'ye take me for threeſcore, you blockhead.

sp.speaker: "Furn.
sp.p: Not I, upon my ſoul, Sir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Leſs angry] Then I ſuppoſe you think me near fifty.

sp.speaker: "Furn.
sp.p: Nothing like it, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Perhaps then, my good friend, you imagine me to be about forty."

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Indeed I do not, Mr. Whimſey.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Shaking hands with him.] Nay, nay, my dear fellow, 'tis impoſſible you can ſuppoſe me to be much under fifty, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Egad but I do tho', ha! ha! ha!— [aſide.] How well he counterfeits the laugh of an old man! [both laugh ſome time.]

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, Furniſh, you are a mighty pleaſant fellow.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p:
I believe I am—I make it a part of my buſineſs to be pleaſant—but there is another part of my buſineſs which I muſt not forget—I have a ſmall bit of paper here—a little ſlip, which I
muſt trouble you to look over [giving him a bill.]

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Certainly—I am always ready to look over the little ſlips of my friends, Mr. Furniſh—let me put on my ſpectacles.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: [aſide] Spectacles, too! he carries on the joke rarely.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [reading] John Whimſey, Eſquire, Debtor, for furniſhing Miſs Fanny Flighty's houſe in Newman-ſtreet!—Why what the devil's all this? I know nothing of Miſs Flighty's houſe in Newman-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: I believe you have paſs'd many a night there.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I paſs the night at Miſs Fanny Flighty's!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Don't think to deceive me, young gentleman—don't I know that you have not paid for the three laſt gigs you had?—that you have as many tricks as a juggler to chouſe your creditors?—that you keep women in every corner of the town, and change them as often as your horſes?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I can't tell what you may know—but curſe me if I know a word of the matter.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: This I know, that I will have my money.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: So you may—but d—n me if you ſhall have any of mine.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Why, you brazen young dog!—you'll break your poor parent's heart.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I'll break your head firſt, however. [Attempting to ſtrike him.]

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Mr. Snap, there's your priſoner.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: I ax your pardon, Maſter Furniſh—he ſhall be no priſoner of mine—Why I find you have miſtaken the father for the ſon—'Tis lucky the buſineſs ſtopt here—Falſe impriſonment is a dangerous miſtake in this land of liberty.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Falſe impriſonment! Bleſs me—why I met a fellow here, who told me a cock and a bull ſtory about you—and yet as gentleman-like a man, with a red morning-gown and a gold-lac'd hat.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [aſide] Eh! i'faith there is ſome trick in all this—My hat and gown have not been borrowed for nothing— [to him] but what a curſed fool muſt you be, to truſt to appearances!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: If I had truſted to your appearance, I ſhould not have miſtaken a gouty old rake of threeſcore for a young rake of two-and-twenty.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Why, you abuſive dirty plebeian—you raſcally vamper of crazy moveables—out of the houſe directly!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: With all my heart—I'm ſure I've no reaſon to like my company—only don't threaten me—if you dare to lay one of your rheumatic old bones upon my perſon—I'll knock you down, I will, egad—Remember, I'm an auctioneer—and to knock down a lot of old lumber is often a part of my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Oh! I am glad you are come—you muſt ſet off for home to-night.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: To-night, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Aye, Ma'am—to-night—I have been plunder'd, abus'd, laugh'd at, and nearly arreſted, all in the courſe of half an hour—"I have loſt my morning-gown and my beſt hat—but I'll find my property, if it is in the houſe.

sp.speaker: "Char.
sp.p: Dear Sir, what can they mean by a trick of that ſort?

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Mean! why, to be witty, to be ſure—I ſuppoſe there is ſome clever creature in the houſe, who, having no room for wit in his ſcull, has learnt to jeſt with his fingers"—I am always treated thus whenever I viſit this curſed town—Thank Heaven, however, I ſhall be off in an hour.—Let all the things be pack'd up again—I'll juſt ſtay to recover my hat and gown—leave a letter to tell Jack he is diſinherited, and then trundle into the country, where the people are not ſufficiently well bred to laugh at the follies of their betters.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: To-night, did my father ſay, we were to ſet off?—"Perhaps he may order the chaiſe even before the hour I've appointed to elope with Monford"—Surely this is about the time Monford was to meet me here—but this unlucky accident!

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, I think there is nothing but unlucky accidents in this houſe—I know you're in love, Ma'am, as well as me—Tim told me all—we are ſuch true lovers, that we never hide any thing from each other.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Am I then betray'd?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I hope not, Ma'am—I'm ſure your ſweetheart muſt be a vile fellow to betray ſuch a pretty lady; and yet there is no anſwering for youth, when they get into company.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What d'ye mean, child?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Young men will be young men—but I didn't think Tim wou'd have ſerv'd me ſo, when he knew the conſequences.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: [aſide] Serve her ſo, when he knew the conſequences!

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am, if you did but know my ſituation.—I tremble to think what a noiſe old miſtreſs will make—I am ſure the whole ſtory will come out. Tim has got—got—got— [ſobbing.]

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: What?—poor girl, I pity her diſtreſs [aſide.]

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: But, perhaps, Ma'am, your gentleman has ſometimes ſerv'd you juſt the ſame—I beg pardon.—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My dear, you really—confuſe me—ſo—what has he got?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p:
He has got—tipſey, Ma'am—and when
he is tipſey he does not care what he does—"I know old miſtreſs will find out that he and I are fallen in love together"—and here he comes, I vow.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How unlucky!—But he won't ſtay in this room, will he?

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Indeed, Ma'am, I can't anſwer for him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: To ſay the truth, my dear girl—I engag'd to meet my lover, as you call him, in this very room, preſently—Pray, contrive that I may not be diſappointed.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I will, indeed, Ma'am, if I poſſibly can—but Tim ſometimes is ſo boiſterous, I'm oblig'd to let him do as he pleaſes— [Exit Charlotte.] Bleſs me—when this love gets into one's head!—I ſhall be ſcolded for not putting this room to rights—
sp.stage: [lets down one of the window curtains; as ſhe begins to let down the other—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh, Nancy! my dear—ſweet—pretty little Nancy! tol de rol [ſinging and dancing.]

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Oh, Tim, how can you be ſo merry in ſuch a ſituation?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Vy every body is merry; and all is merry round me—The very tables and chairs dance—and you know the old ſaying, ven one is at Rome, one muſt do as Rome does.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Pray ſit down.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I will, as you ax me ſo civilly— [ſits down in a chair.] Oh, Nancy! how I do love you.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Conſider, Tim.—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I can't conſider—I can do nothing but be in love—and one can do that without conſidering at all.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: I wiſh you wou'd go to-bed, my dear Tim—Do, take my advice.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I will, Nancy, my dear—I will take your advice.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Come, then.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I am going—I am going.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: But you don't ſtir—Hark! I hear ſomebody on the ſtairs—make haſte.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I will—I tell you I am going.

sp.speaker: Nancy.
sp.p: Lord! if the old woman ſhould catch me here—I am ſo frighten'd—here ſomebody comes, I vow—What ſhall I do?—I muſt e'en leave him to himſelf.—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Don't be in a hurry, my love—you ſee I am going—going—going— [falls aſleep]

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: I can't conceive where Charlotte can be—ſhe ought to have been punctual at this time, when the criſis of our fate approaches—when— [Tim ſnores] Hey-day! what have we here? my friend Timothy ſtopt ſhort on his journey to bed, and fallen aſleep by the way—Huſh! I hear a noiſe on the ſtairs—let me liſten. [Retires."]

div.stage: Enter YOUNG WHIMSEY, on the other Side.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Egad, I have had a hard chace of it—the old gentleman cou'd not have been warmer in the purſuit, if he had been hunting a petticoat—What the deuce is this? old Mother Pattypan's huſband elect!—My father's voice again!—I ſhould like to ſee the end of the joke—but where can I hide myſelf?—i'faith this window curtain wou'd keep me out of ſight, and at the ſame time give me an opportunity of hearing what paſſes; and, leſt Mr. Timothy ſhould catch cold, I'll lend him my ſpoils to cover him, as I have no further uſe for them— [lays the gown over Tim Tartlett, and puts the hat on his head] But the ſound ſeems to retire, I'll follow it.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: There are voices on the ſtairs, ſure enough—I muſt n't be ſeen here—and yet, if I quit the ſpot, I ſhall miſs the opportunity of ſeeing Charlotte—but hold, a buſtle again!—if a convenient cloſet cou'd be found now—not one in the room, by all that's unlucky!—however, here is a curtain will do juſt as well— [Seems to liſten at the corner of the ſcene, and Young Whimſey enters on the oppoſite ſide.]

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p:
[Aſide] And now, having ſet all my puppets in motion, I retire behind the curtain, like a cunning ſtateſman, from the ſtorm I have rais'd. [Y. Whimſey and Monford ſteal ſoftly from
oppoſite ſides of the ſtage, towards the curtain; and do not perceive each other till they are both on the point of concealing themſelves behind it.]

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Zounds! who is this?

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Really, Sir, this is an extraordinary—a moſt unexpected viſit.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: I muſt own, Sir, it was not intended for you.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: I am at preſent peculiarly circumſtanc'd.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: Exactly my caſe.

sp.speaker: "Monf."
sp.p: I muſt beg you will quit theſe appartments immediately; you'll pardon my abruptneſs.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, make no apologies; it is not the firſt time I have been deſired to quit theſe appartments—but conſtancy is my foible—I never could bear to leave my lodgings till I was turn'd out of them.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: [Aſide] A ſtrange fellow!— [to him]" I expect a perſon here preſently, from whom I muſt be conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: And I have choſen this place for my retreat.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: There we agree, my dear Sir; "and here's a curtain for each of us."

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Zounds! this impertinence.—

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Piano, my dear, Sir, piano!—If you muſt ſwear, let it be in a whiſper—conſider, you will diſcover yourſelf.—

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: [Aſide] Egad, that's very true.

sp.speaker: OLD WHIMSEY without.
sp.p: I'll warrant you I'll ferret the dog out at laſt.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: There, Sir—you have no time to loſe—we muſt purſue the old Engliſh policy—forget our private diſputes, when the common enemy is at the door—and ſo, Sir, in we go.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Where can this thief be hid! I am ſure I have ſearch'd the houſe from the cellar to the garret, as narrowly as if I had been bred an exciſeman— [ſeeing Tim.] Oh! here is the facetious gentleman—aſleep too; ha, ha!—"perhaps it is the perfection of humour to commit a robbery, and pretend to fall aſleep with the ſtolen goods upon him." Come, my lad, you may as well open your eyes—it don't ſignify your ſitting there, and ſnoring like a damag'd organ-pipe—Halloo!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: [waking] Nancy, my dear Nancy—I am going.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Indeed you are not going—What are you, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A little tipſey, your honour.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: How did you come by this hat and morning-gown?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I came by 'em! You ſhould rather aſk, how they came by me.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: What made you ſit down here?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Becauſe I cou'd not ſtand.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Quite intoxicated!—a thorough-bred rogue, I'll warrant him—How have you manag'd ſo long to eſcape hanging, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Your honour ſeems to have liv'd many years longer than me in the vorld, without an accident; and why ſhou'd not I have as good luck as my neighbours?

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: Why you ſcurrilous—but your being tipſey is ſome excuſe for your impertinence.

sp.speaker: "Tim.
sp.p: Then if your honour was to get tipſey, you wou'd have ſome excuſe for yours."

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ha, ha!—he has a budget of jokes too—all ſecond-hand, I ſuppoſe—ſtick to that, my boy—you'll find it much ſafer to ſteal jokes than gold-lac'd hats.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well, your honour, I ſuppoſe you have no commands for me.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: No; I won't trouble you with any, as you won't obey them.— [Sits down]"

sp.speaker: "Tim.
sp.p: As you have nothing further to ſay to me," I'll e'en finiſh my nap.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: By all means, my lad—and when you are ſober, I wou'd have you exchange your wit, for a little honeſty, if you can find any at market—good by t'ye.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: [Peeping from behind the curtain] One of them is gone.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Eh! what's that?

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: [Peeping from the other ſide of the curtain.] Which of them is it?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p:
[Aſide.] Another voice!—There is more miſchief going forward in this houſe.—I'll liſten.
— [lays himſelf back in the chair, puts on the hat, and covers himſelf with the gown.]

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: The old gentleman is off—I don't hear his tongue—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide.] It is my plague!—it is Jack, a I live.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, here lies Tim, taking a ſecond nap: "all dullneſs and finery, like an eaſtern prince at a maſquerade."—I perceive you are ſurpriz'd at his appearance—you muſt know I was his dreſſer.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: In imitation of dame Fortune, I have depriv'd one man of what he really wanted, to laviſh it on another, who had no uſe for it.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Well, Sir; as the circumſtances under which we met prove that each of us have ſome reaſons for wiſhing to be conceal'd at preſent—

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: I'll e'en take my leave;—but before I go, upon my ſoul I long to have one knock at that raſcal, who lies ſleeping there—You muſt know, he has had the impudence to be my rival, with a deviliſh pretty little black-ey'd wench who twirls a mop in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide] Zounds! I believe the dog has diſcover'd me.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: Do, let me fetch a horſe-whip.

sp.speaker: "Whim.
sp.p: A horſe-whip! [Aſide.] Oh!

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: Conſider, what a diſturbance it will raiſe.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: The rogue is ſo tipſey, he won't be able to tell who did it.

sp.speaker: "Monf.
sp.p: Conſider the alarm."

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Do, let me fetch a horſe-whip—I aſk but for three cuts at him—only three cuts—Zounds! here come Mrs. Pattypan—Then I'm off—and Tim may ſleep on in whole bones.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: [To Mrs. Patt.] Ah! Mrs. Pattypan—I ſuppoſe you are in ſearch of your apprentice—there he ſits, in a kind of double diſguiſe, both of dreſs and liquor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir, I have heard of it all; and ſhall give him a lecture on the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [Aſide.] The devil!—it will be a fine joke againſt me to be diſcover'd in this ſituation—I'll e'en feign to be aſleep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Oh, Tim Tartlett! I did mean to ſcold you—but your preſence ſoftens all my reſentment.—"That old fool, our new lodger's father, has been turning the houſe out at the window in ſearch of his hat and morning-gown—which I ſee you had taken in a joke.—My dear Tim, you don't anſwer me."—Come, you muſt not be too baſhful—you have to be ſure taken a liberty, by your conduct this evening—but when a woman loves a man—ſhe can pardon little liberties in him. [taking his hand.]

div.stage: Enter CHARLOTTE and MONFORD, with his arm round her waiſt, as if talking to her—Mrs. PATTYPAN ſtarts, and OLD WHIMSEY diſcovers herſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Upon my word, ma'am, this intruſion—

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Is a very agreeable intruſion, Mrs. Pattypan—I really began to be afraid of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Afraid of me—but I won't be out of temper.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I declare, I thought it was Mr. Timothy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: "[aſide] Oh you did! yes, yes, they are going off to-night; but I'll watch them."—Yes, ma'am, I thought it was Mr. Timothy too.—The old gentleman cou'd never ſuppoſe I meant to make love to him—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Faith I don't know, Mrs. Pattypan—the love of ſome ladies is a kind of univerſal philanthropy—it extends to all mankind— [Exit Mrs. Patt.] And pray, Sir, did you think it was Mr. Timothy too?—In ſhort, Monford, we have all paſſed a mighty agreeable evening, and it is now time to go to bed.—One word at parting—if you marry Mrs. Pattyman—you had better continue to keep a ſharp look out after Mr. Timothy.—"Depend upon it, you'll often meet with him where you don't expect to find him."—So good-night t' ye. [Exeunt Whimſey and Charlotte; and Monford on the oppoſite ſide.]

div.head: SCENE changes, and diſcovers the doors of four Rooms.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: A pretty ſcrape you have led me into by your inattention, in not bringing me my father's letter—you blundering blockhead!

sp.speaker: "Simon.
sp.p: Indeed, your honour"—

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Rot your excuſes—Let me ſee—you ſay the gentleman who took ſhelter with me behind the window-curtain, is Mr. Monford, my ſiſter Charlotte's lover.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, and he is going to run away with her this evening.

sp.speaker: "Y. Whim.
sp.p: How did you learn that?

sp.speaker: "Simon.
sp.p: Why he ſent me to order a chaiſe at the Red Lion. When I came there, who ſhou'd I meet but Squire Monford's ſervant, who was come on the very ſame errand?—I gueſs'd what the chaiſe was wanted for—but I ſaid never a word"—I know where they order'd the chaiſe.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Then run back inſtantly to the inn, and countermand Mr. Monford's chaiſe in his name—I'll take the conſequences—when the other comes, tell the poſtboy to let me know—I'll ſtep into the room which I find was intended for my father—the old gentleman will hardly go into it, as he does not mean to ſleep there—be quick—don't loſe a moment.
sp.stage: [Exit Young Whimſey into the firſt room.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh! Monford—my father has order'd me to meet him in his room directly—the moment your chaiſe is ready come to me in my chamber—Remember that fartheſt door is mine, and don't venture to ſpeak above a whiſper.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: My charmer—my Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Huſh! this is not a time for fine ſpeeches—I'm ſure I hear my father's footſteps—I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Well done, old Whimſey—who will pretend to deny that I am an excellent politician!—to ſet off at a moment's notice—without giving Monford the moſt diſtant inkling of my intentions!—Egad, I ſhall jockey them all; and leave Jack to pay for the lodgings as well as he can—and now I'll e'en retire to my own room, and wait for Charlotte.
sp.stage: [Goes into the room where his ſon is concealed—ſhuts the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: My young madam's door open!—That's the ſignal I ſuppoſe for Mr. Timothy to wait on her—but ſhe is miſtaken—at theſe years I think I know the value of a lover too well to loſe him ſo eaſily—but I hear ſomebody coming, and I muſt not be ſeen here—I'll e'en ſtep into my new lodger's room for a minute, till they are gone.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: That muſt be Charlotte, by her tiptoe tread, and the ruſtling of her gown—but then why retire into my room inſtead of her own—I'll follow her however—the devil take the people, will they never be in bed in this houſe?
sp.stage: [Exit into the room where Mrs. Pattypan is gone.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What ſhall I do!—I fear I am not quite ſober yet; that plaguy old woman haunts me like a ghoſt—By jingo, I believe here ſhe comes—Where ſhall I hide myſelf?—Here is a door open, i'faith—any port in a ſtorm, they ſay.
sp.stage: [Exit into the third room, and ſhuts the door.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I think the whole houſe is now at reſt, except our faithful Nancy.—My father is undoubtedly in his own chamber—My door is ſhut; ſo Monford is certainly gone into my room—Lud, I'm ſo frighten'd—I wiſh I were ſafe out of the houſe.
sp.stage: [Exit into the room where Tim Tartlett is gone.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I'll bring you to my maſter, my lad—he'll give you his orders here.

sp.speaker: Poſtboy.
sp.p:
I ſuppoſe his honor pays handſomely—
travels with a ſilver ſpur, eh!—I've all my paces—from eighteen pence to five ſhillings a ſtage—But where is the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I'faith that's more than I can tell—perhaps he is in his bed-chamber—but which it is of thoſe rooms I'm ſure I don't know—Stay here a moment, while I ſtep down ſtairs and enquire.

sp.speaker: Poſtboy.
sp.p: And ſo I'm to kick my heels here while he is looking for his maſter, and my horſes ſtanding in the ſtreet all the while.—I'll e'en try all the doors—I ſhall find the right one at laſt [Knocking at each of the doors in turn] Nobody anſwers—rot me, if I don't believe the people are all aſleep—Halloo! gentlefolks!—the chaiſe is ready— [cracking his whip] [All the doors fly open at once, and the ſeveral perſons who had concealed themſelves in the rooms come out.]

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: [taking Jack Whimſey's hand] Come along, Charlotte—come along—Hey-day!—how did you come here, you dog? [looking round him] and you?—and you?—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Heavens! we are diſcover'd! [turning round, and ſeeing Tim] Bleſs me! Mr. Timothy!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am—you are diſcover'd, indeed.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: Mr. Whimſey!—I'm really all confuſion!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p:
Yes, faith—ſo the reſt of the company ſeem to be.—Here we are—fat and lean—old and young—pair'd as badly as the city train-bands at
a Lord Mayor's ſhow—But how the devil we came here in couples, ſeems as yet to remain a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: I can explain it—Your ſhameleſs daughter ſeduced the affections of my intended huſband; and has attempted to tear him from my arms.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Tear him from your arms!—Egad, I ſhou'd think that no eaſy matter, Mrs. Pattypan, if you were reſolved to hold him faſt.

sp.speaker: Monf.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, my confeſſion will explain every thing to you.—I own I did intend to elope with Miſs Charlotte this evening.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Very obliging of you, indeed—to make a confeſſion, when your ſcheme is diſcover'd—I have ſeen a highwayman do as much juſt before his execution.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Then, Sir, as execution follows confeſſion—let them be tied up directly—with Benefit of Clergy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Suppoſe you and I follow the example, Miſtreſs!—I believe my hour is come; and ſo the ſooner I am out of my pain, the better.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Patt.
sp.p: Then Tim is conſtant, after all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ah! Miſtreſs, that I am— [Sighing.]

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My dear father will not let me petition in vain.

sp.speaker: Y. Whim.
sp.p: Nay—Nancy will join her entreaties; and then, Sir, you will a ſecond time be between two fires.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ah! rot your two fires!—the dog has me faſt—I dare not refuſe my conſent; and ſo, Monford, take my daughter; but curſe me, if I intended you ſhou'd have had her.—As for you, Mrs. Pattypan—may you find marriage like one of your own tarts, with no more acid in in, than is juſt enough to render the ſweets more poignant.—To crown your ſatisfaction, may your lodgings never remain empty; and may every friend who takes a peep at the Firſt Floor, honour it with their approbation.
